headline: Pennsylvania court strikes down state's mail-in voting law
sentences: Three Republican judges sided with Republicans who had challenged the law, Act 77, saying the state’s constitution required people to vote in person unless they had a specific excuse, such as having a disability or being away from home on Election Day.

Article content
A Pennsylvania court has found a no-excuses mail-in voting law to violate the state’s constitution, raising doubts over access to the ballot in the battleground state ahead of important election contests later this year.

Commonwealth Court President Judge Mary Hannah Leavitt said that while she believed the people of Pennsylvania would support a constitutional amendment ending a requirement for in-person voting, an amendment was still a necessary step.

“An amendment to our Constitution that ends the requirement of in-person voting is the necessary prerequisite to the legislature’s establishment of a no-excuse mail-in voting system,” Leavitt wrote in the ruling.

Republicans changed their views on the law after Trump lost the state, with many of them embracing the former president’s false claims that widespread fraud tied to mail-in ballots was behind his defeat.
Republicans were seeking to end straight-ticket voting, which had allowed voters to select one political party’s slate of candidates, and Democrats wanted to open up voting-by-mail to everyone.
Pennsylvania’s Democratic attorney general said the Commonwealth Court’s ruling on Friday would be immediately appealed to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, however.
